bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Frederick L. Rath, Jr., November 17, 1951

div1.p: Hench writes Rath that he would appreciate any help that the National Trust for Historic Preservation could provide in preserving Camp Lazear. He describes his attempts to enlist the support of the Cuban government and the Rockefeller Foundation.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Frederick L. Rath, Jr., November 17, 1951
div1.opener:
November 17, 1951
Mr. Frederick L. Rath, Jr.
Director
National Trust for Historic Preservation
The Octagon House
Washington, 6, D.C.
My dear Mr. Rath:
div1.p:
I appreciate very greatly your letter of November 6 commenting on the
little article which appeared in the New York Times for Sunday, Novem-
ber 4, the article concerning the little Building No. 1 of Walter Reed.
Will you kindly note especially the last part (pages 3 to 7) of my article
“Walter Reed and the Conquest of Yellow Fever” in The Pharos for May, 1948?
That will give you the details of our rediscovery of the little building.
What the little building was used for is described in all of the reprints
and a photograph of the building appears in two or three of them.

I would certainly appreciate any advice and help that your organization
can give me. Being a very busy physician, it has not been possible for
me to campaign individually and write hundreds of letters to collect
nickels and dimes for this project. When Mr. Moran and I discovered the
little building in 1940, I discussed the letter with Doctor Ramos, then
Secretary of Defense. Doctor Ramos is a Cuban physician greatly interested
in the story of Walter Reed as well as the story of Finlay and a man who
had previously written an article suggesting the preservation of the wrong
Camp Lazear. In 1940 Doctor Ramos listened to our ideas with a great
interest and promised help but shortly thereafter he went out of office
and did nothing.

On two occasions when I gave this story, first at the dedication of the
Lazear Memorial Building at Washington and Jefferson College and then
when I told it again at the unveiling of the Cornwell painting during
the meeting of the American Medical Association, June 1941, in Cleveland,
I hinted to my audiences that I hoped that money could be collected for
the preservation of the little building but no help was forthcoming.

Thereafter I made two or three trips to Cuba and on my last trip in 1948
I really thought I had gotten somewhere. As a result of a previous trip
the Cuban government had accepted the authenticity of the little shack,
had allowed the memorial sign at the false Camp Lazear to fall down and
become destroyed and had made the little shack a “national memorial” but
they had done absolutely nothing to preserve the shack. During my 1948
trip I visited various governmental officials, including the Vice-President
of Cuba. I showed them a tentative plan regarding a memorial to be

erected on the spot. This plan was approved heartily by the head of the
Engineering Department, by the Minister of Health and by the Vice-Presi-
dent, who welcomed me kindly to his home. I found the shack deteriorated
even worse than before and how it has survived the various tornadoes that
hit Cuba every two or three years is incredible. Although the Cuban
government had made the little shack and the land on which it stands a
national monument, I found that this actually was a deterrent rather than
a help to my plan. I went to the owner of the land on which the little
shack stands (Mr. Adrian Macia) and asked if he wouldn't let me buy the
little property. He said that he couldn't because it was a national monu-
ment. I then asked him if he would let me pay the expense of having a
galvanized iron covering put over the little building that would at least
protect it until the Cubans got around to doing something. He said he
hadn't the authority to let me do that either. When I repeated this
request gently and diplomatically to the Vice-President, the latter, with
typical Cuban protestations and gestures, assured me that the Cuban
government could never allow me to spend my own money; that the Cuban
government would immediately take steps to protect the little building
until such time as the full memorial project could be developed. I was
rather discouraged but true to his word, he and others did put through
the Cuban congress a bill to allot $50,000 for the project. This was
passed rather promptly and two or three clippings to that effect were
sent to me by Cuban friends in 1948. I had high hopes for the project.

My project envisaged the erection of a Cuban-style building on the spot,
a large room of which would actually enclose the little building. Around
the walls of this room would be various photographs and other data per-
taining to the work of Finlay, Walter Reed and his American colleagues.
The rest of the building would be devoted to a small public health unit
for that little suburb of Quemados, which is without such a unit but which
needs one badly. The rest of Camp Lazear would be made into a small park
with a little inexpensive central memorial on the site of Building No. 2.
My advisors in this plan were Dr. Pedro Nogueira, a very aggressive and
fine young Quemados physician interested in public health in Quemados,
and also Mr. Johnny Moran, one of Reed's original guinea pigs.

To my dismay, once more that party went out of power. They lost the
next election and none of my Cuban friends or I have ever been able to
learn what happened to the $50,000. I have been told confidentially that
it either went into the pockets of the Cuban officials “in the usual
manner” or it was spent on some other project.

From time to time I have seen and tried to interest certain Americans in
this project. Some years ago, when Nelson Rockefeller was head of some
sort of a bureau which had to do with Latin-American cultural relation-
ships, I tried to interest him in this project but just about the time I
saw him his bureau folded up. With Doctor Sawyer, head of the Rockefeller
Foundation, I saw Mr. John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s chief advisor in charitable
matters. Doctor Sawyer and I thought that, because the Rockefeller Founda-
tion has been so interested in yellow fever, Mr. Rockefeller's advisors
regarding donations might be interested. I regret to say that this man
received me and showed little sympathy with the project, stating that he
thought it was outside the realm of interest of their charity.

I have talked about this at some length with both of the past Surgeons
General (not the present one) and they were both strongly in favor of
it and will do whatever is necessary. But the up-shot of it is that
nothing constructive has happened and I can summarize the present posi-
tion briefly:
(1) I doubt if the Cuban Government will authorize the proper expenditures
unless (a) the Cuban funds are matched by American donations or (b) unless
some Americans in official positions can get behind the unofficial efforts
of myself and others to persuade the Cuban government to carry on the proj-
ect.
(2) The fact that the Cuban government has made the little building a
national monument prevents any private American or Cuban from doing
anything, even temporarily to preserve the shack.
(3) I regret to say that from my experience I must conclude that one
can place little reliance on the very friendly and temporarily enthusiastic
attitude of any Cuban. Three strong forces in Cuba prevent, at present,
the accomplishment of my desires: (a) The ingrained attitude of manana,
their eternal procrastination despite the most solemn promises; (b) what
my Cuban advisors privately tell me about the common grafting by officials
of money set aside for this or that project; and (c) the fact that in
Cuba there is still a great controversy between those who would give all
the credit to Finlay and none to Walter Reed and those who are willing,
rather grudgingly, to give Walter Reed and his associates some credit for
the conquest of yellow fever. Twice since 1948 I have received newspaper
clippings showing officials visiting Walter Reed's little shack and despite
the absolute evidence, the photographs have been labelled “The little shack
where Finlay proved the cause of yellow fever.”

Despite all my discouragements I feel that I must keep trying and I am going
to Cuba again in January. The people who own the land, Mr. Macia and the
Rojas family, are still quite interested in the project as is Doctor
Nogueira. I am sure that a few of the Cuban officials are quite sincere
and it is a wonderful opportunity that in erecting a Cuban-American memorial
honoring in full measure Finlay as well as Reed and his associates, a
rapprochement can be accomplished and the painful argument between those
who would honor only Finlay and those who would honor only Reed can be
done away with finally in a spirit of real cordiality and admiration. I
might add that on one of my visits I met President Batista who expressed
approval of the project but of course did nothing.

The Walter Reed Memorial Association knows fully of my hopes and plans.
Walter Reed's daughter and son, Lazear's son and daughter also know and
fully approve. If we could only get organized and get official backing
strong enough to impress the Cuban government so that they would not go
back on their word, I am sure that we could put over this project but I
regret that acting alone, I have not gotten anywhere to date.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, MD. PSH:alc
